Through you, Madam President: Senator Harris, if you read some of the four-wheel drive magazines, as I do, you will find those magazines warning their readers to be very careful about purchasing some of these imported four-wheel drive vehicles which are not set up for Australian conditions. They are made in Japan for Japanese conditions. Their specifications do not suit Australia at all. They suffer significant problems with overheating, they have radiators and other things that are made not for Australian conditions but for Japanese conditions. So there are serious problems with them. We have put very strict limits on the extent to which you can bring in diesel variants of four-wheel drive vehicles that are available in Australia and that meet Australian design conditions and standards. There is a huge range of four-wheel drive vehicles available to Australian purchasers in this country. It is one of the most open markets in the world.

—My question is to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. In light of the gross blow-outs in budget and time frames being experienced in the Howard government's headlong rush to outsource every scrap of its information technology framework, can the minister inform the Senate just what the American consultants Shaw Pittman have achieved for the Australian public interest in return for the exorbitant and outrageous amounts of taxpayers' money they are being paid? How has this American firm actually earned their $85,000 per month for a single consultant, or a total contract worth $25.78 million for three individual contractors? In light of these blow-outs in budget and time frames and the poor quality end results, will the government be considering suing Shaw Pittman for the return of these millions?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I know that the Labor Party hate IT outsourcing. They hate it so much that they are prepared to continue with it as their policy if they get into government, which tells you that there is just the usual ongoing struggle with the trade unions, who would like to see all this work done in-house—where the membership is—and who are terrified that it might actually go outside government and therefore represent a significant benefit to Australia.

answer.para: The Auditor's report on this has confirmed that there have been considerable savings to government. It has made some suggestions about how the process might be improved, but it ought to be quite clear that there are still considerable benefits to be gained from going down the IT outsourcing track. The predicted savings, for example, for cluster 3, group 5, the Australian tax office, the health group and group 8 contracts over the initial five-year term is over $265 million, a significant achievement for the government. So the estimates of ultimate value might be disputed but I do not think anyone can seriously claim that this is a process that has not been of benefit to Australia. I am not in a position to reveal what Shaw Pittman might have reported to the government. As to some of the more draconian suggestions by Senator Campbell, I presume that is just pure vitriol and he wants to get something off his chest.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, isn't Shaw Pittman one of the prime examples of blow-outs in consul-tancy fees paid in overseas currency which have recently been so roundly criticised by the Commonwealth Auditor-General? What is the government's response to the Auditor-General when he states:

quote.para: Contracts requiring foreign currency payments expose the Commonwealth to foreign exchange risk and reduce the certainty associated with the costs of the contract.

question.para: Isn't the Shaw Pittman IT outsourcing contract an absolute case in point, Minister?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I think it is an example of how you can have cost overruns or costs being incurred beyond the original budget. You ought to know a lot about that because you have been past masters in your day. The ANAO itself calculates that the implementation costs represent about 3.2 per cent of the value of the five contracts awarded to date. So, whilst Senator Campbell might find it convenient to nibble away at the edges and to criticise the fact that the ultimate cost in relation to Shaw Pittman is higher than originally expected, he should be concentrating on the main game, which is whether or not there is a significant benefit to Australia from these outsourcing arrangements. It is the government's view that not only is outsourcing something that this government is doing; it is something that governments around the world are doing and that all the major corporates are doing. If you look at the way in which organisations like Cisco operate, even though the product might be badged `Cisco' it is all done by 100 or more equipment manufacturers. It is about time you got with the strength and buried your trade union hatreds. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald. Will the minister outline to the Senate the significant benefits for regional and remote Australia from the first two partial sales of Telstra? Is the minister aware of any alternative approaches to the provision of additional funding for regional Australia from the partial sales of Telstra?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Senator Ferris has a real interest in rural and regional Australia and in the environment. She will know that this government has made the biggest investment ever in the environment—some $1 billion. Senator Ferris, that $1 billion investment in the environment—the biggest made by any government in Australia—was as a result of the sale of Telstra. That was opposed by the Labor Party then and still is, which shows they have no interest in the environment and no interest in helping in rural and regional Australia.

answer.para: As well as that, the sale of Telstra 1 and 2 has meant that the government have been able to provide very significant enhancements to life in rural and regional Australia in the telecommunications area. We are providing $120 million for a television fund which will extend SBS into rural and regional Australia and $45 million to local government to help get them on-line, mainly in rural and regional Australia. We are spending $28 million from the sale of Telstra to expand mobile phone coverage and $150 million to provide untimed local calls to rural and regional Australians. These are all things that are very much appreciated in rural and regional Australia and are all things which have been opposed from day one by the Australian Labor Party.

I am asked by Senator Ferris as well: do I know of any other policy approaches? I am aware that the Labor Party always promised they would not sell Qantas and Australian Airlines, and yet when they had the opportunity, what did they do? They sold Qantas and they sold Australian Airlines. They promised they would never sell the Commonwealth Bank. Never, never, never would they sell the Commonwealth Bank. And yet what did the Australian Labor Party do? They sold it as soon as they had the opportunity. They promised never to sell CSL, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. They sold that too. In fact, they sold everything they could get their hands on, and Mr Beazley said a few years ago that he would also sell Telstra. Then a couple of months back, Mr Beazley said this:

quote.para: No Labor government presided over by me will continue the privatisation of Telstra, full stop—

answer.para: meaning he would never sell it. But we know Mr Beazley finds it difficult to understand the truth. We know from his previous actions that he will sell Telstra as soon as possible, but he still denies it. Now we have confirmation in the Macquarie search equities newsletter, in which it is quite clearly shown that senior members of the Labor Party are now talking to the major finance people about selling Telstra—about privatising Telstra, when Mr Beazley is promising not to do it. Senator Cook, I suggest, it may have been; it is in his area; or Senator Conroy, not here today; or Senator Forshaw, from the right; it is something he would agree with. Mr Beazley says he doesn't know who these senior people in the Labor Party are—the people who are proposing to sell Telstra. We ought to get the inquiry into who said the comment about the toilet brush on the Titanic—that inquiry that Mr Beazley implemented, which is pretty slow coming to a conclusion—to have a look at who leaked this. Was it Senator Cook? Was it Senator Forshaw? Was it Senator Conroy? Who was it? Who is it that actually is speaking with these senior finance houses? While they are at it, looking for these lost things in the Labor Party, perhaps they could implement an inquiry into what happened to the word `roll-back', which also seems to have been lost. It is now `roll over'. We have a good inquiry up my way in Townsville into ALP vote rigging—deliberate vote rigging. Perhaps we should have these other inquiries as well. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Alston, representing the Prime Minister. How does the minister justify the government's decision to back away from signing the UN optional protocol to the Convention for the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Australia has an excellent record on women's rights. We should be agreed on that. Are we agreed on that? We took a leadership position by ratifying CEDAW in 1983. Australia has a world-class regime of legislation and institutional mechanisms to protect women against discrimination.
—That was us in 1983.

—Well, if you don't think we are part of the country, then you are part of the problem. We remain very strongly committed to protecting and supporting the rights of women. In other words, we are not walking away from our UN obligations or our human rights goals.
—What about your mother—what does she say about it? What about your brother?
—I told you I was the failure of the family!

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! I am waiting for a level of order in the chamber so that we may proceed. The chamber is behaving in a disorderly fashion.
—You might be the next centrefold, Richard.
—One thing is for sure: I don't think I will be competing with you. I think our concerns with the UN treaty system are well known. They were identified many long years ago by Senator Kemp.
—Your brother doesn't agree.

—I think you might find that Senator Kemp and my brother have more in common than you might suspect. The problems with the UN treaty system are deep-seated. They do need sensible economic analysis, and on the basis of that Senator Kemp was able to come up with a very intelligent contribution to policy debate. In fact, that is one of the main reasons that he is with us today on the front bench, because he made such an outstanding contribution to this debate. What it did was to cause the government to have a look at whether or not there was room for improvement in the UN committee system. The UN Human Rights Commissioner shares our concerns that there is room for improvement. In fact, I think you will find that many people on the international stage, even if they don't agree, say more money ought to be spent on the issue. But no-one is terribly happy with current arrangements. So in those circumstances we do not think it is appropriate for Australia to sign the optional protocol while those concerns remain. Like any organisation that has been in business now for more than 50 years, you can get some arteriosclerosis; you can find that parts of the organisation need to be reformed. We believe that in the UN treaty system we do not like to be pontificated towards; we do think that there can be a much more constructive approach taken. When those concerns have been addressed, then of course we will revisit the issue.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the government reconsider its refusal to sign the optional protocol in the light of a letter of protest to the Prime Minister which has been sent by 200 women's groups, including the Young Women's Christian Association, from right across the political spectrum?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I do not know about that. I would not have thought that `right across the political spectrum' necessarily means one Christian group and 199 others. I can remember that during the 1993 election, when I was in the child-care portfolio, there were about 15 groups suddenly popped up criticising our child-care policy. We tracked them all back to the Trades Hall Council. The mere fact that there were 15 bodies does not represent a spectrum of political opinion. I think you might be overstating the case a tad. I think what you are really saying is that around the world you are able to mobilise a group of people who do not share our view of the world. That is not surprising—there may well be a lot of people who do not agree with us on a number of issues. But, again, we accept that in a democracy that is their right, and no doubt they will continue to vociferously argue their position. We, on the other hand, will argue ours. We will push for constructive reform. It is sad, really, that you just feel yourself obliged to blindly pursue what you see as a political opportunity.

subdebateinfo.title: United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women

talk.start.para: —I have a very similar question, but I would now like to ask it of Senator Newman in the hope that we really can get an answer. Given that we now have some 200 women's groups that have signed the letter of protest—indeed, I would also like to ask the minister whether she knows of any women's groups that have not signed this letter—is it not the case that Australia would be far—
—Order! Senator Faulkner, I need to hear the question.

—I ask the minister: does she not believe that it is far better to work from within for the reforms that this government is claiming are necessary rather than send a message to those countries that regularly and actively discriminate against women that it is fine to pull away from the table and not sign this optional protocol?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I have a list here of the non-signatories to the optional protocol, a list which goes for several pages. Australia is not out on a limb on this matter. Certainly, in terms of our dissatisfaction—
—Madam President, I cannot speak over the constant conversation from Senator Faulkner.
—Senator Lees is entitled to hear the answer.
—If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen!
—Senator Campbell, I have just drawn the opposition's attention to the fact that Senator Lees is entitled to hear the answer. You should stop shouting.
—Senator Campbell might not realise that before he came to the Senate it was a much more polite and courteous place. Australia does believe in UN obligations—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Lees asked me a question and I am trying to give her the answer. The government do believe in honouring our UN treaty obligations, and we have continued to do that constantly throughout our 4½ years in government in terms of women and CEDAW. In June we supported women's NGOs to go with us to the UN to report on our activities in this country since Beijing. It was the Beijing Plus Five meeting. After that meeting, when we came back to Australia, I had a number of letters from women's NGOs saying how much they appreciated the support which I, the Office of the Status of Women and the government had given to their representation and their effort there. I think that these were genuine letters that were appreciative of the support that we give to women, both within Australia and overseas.

answer.para: Nevertheless, many people in the UN, on its staff, will say to you that this is an organisation which needs reform. It is entirely unsatisfactory that our reports on CEDAW are reviewed by the UN committee concerned two years at least after they are submitted, by which time obviously they are pretty much out of date and things have changed quite considerably. If we could get the UN committees to be more efficient, this government would have a great deal more time for the claims that are being made about our representations on women. We are supportive of women's rights in this country and we support women's rights overseas. But we do not support the right of unelected officials in the UN to not do their job and to take a perspective on various committees which is not consistent with the information that is given to them by governments.

All of this has been spelled out by the foreign minister quite clearly. As you people have highlighted, the optional protocol is one that we helped with; we worked towards trying to get language that was better. Australia was there during that working process over quite a long time. So you cannot extrapolate from the fact that we have refused to sign the optional protocol and say that we are not supportive of the UN, that we are not supportive of women and that we are not supportive of the role of the UN in looking to see that women's rights are upheld around the world. Nevertheless, something has to be done at the UN to make it a more efficient body which is doing its job properly.

talk.start.para: —I can hear Senator Crowley chirping in the back. As a former minister, she should know very well that women are not served by an organisation that cannot even run its committees efficiently. If the committees are not up to date, if they are two to three years out of date in reviewing countries' reports, then they are doing the women of the world no favour whatsoever.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister certainly is correct in saying that Australian women have been actively involved in the process of drawing this up—that is why so many are very disappointed in this government's decision not to sign. I ask the minister: surely she would agree that we have now sent a very clear message that we are not happy with the UN process and the fact that, thanks to the lack of resources, often time lines are not adequate and are not met. But now that we have sent the message, isn't it time to send another message to many of those countries that you indicated have not signed? I would suggest that most of the Western democracies have signed or are going to sign. Many of the countries on that list are those that actively discriminate against women. Isn't it now about time that we put our signatures there? Doesn't that send the clearest message possible that we are supportive of the document?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to that is no, it doesn't, unless you keep the pressure on, and you have got to see results to know whether the pressure has been successful. As to the countries signing or ratifying this agreement, a number of Western countries have not done either, and of course the United States has never ever signed the basic CEDAW convention. Does that mean—and it clearly does not—that the United States does not believe in the rights of women? That is not true.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —On Wednesday, 4 October 2000 Senator Ludwig asked me a question concerning a Sydney based tax officer, Mr Lowman Chow, and a visit that was made to Canberra. I seek leave to have the answer now incorporated in the Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.

para.inline: The answer read as follows—

quote.para: It is assumed that the Senator read this in the Business Review Weekly of 22 September 2000 on page 53 in the context of speculation about claims to be made by the defence in a case currently before the courts relating to Mr Petroulias. As the Opposition is aware, those issues are sub judice and the ATO has received advice that they should not comment on anything before the Court.

However, the ATO has been able to make some general comments. The ATO advises that during 1998, meetings were held in Canberra within the ATO which included discussions and input on issues involving employee share benefit arrangements. ATO meetings to discuss current tax matters are routine.

It was concluded that no changes to FBT legislation was necessary in respect of the employee share benefit arrangements being discussed at that time, because the schemes were not effective under the existing law.
The Government received advice from the ATO that the existing law was sufficient.

When the Government received advice in mid-June 2000 regarding legislation changes needed to address continued promotion of some arrangements. This was on the basis that such schemes were still being marketed. The Government responded quickly to announce legislative amendment on 30 June.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs: Le Monde Article

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (Senator Alston), to a question without notice asked by Sen-ator Bolkus today, relating to comments made by the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation (Mr Ruddock) concerning Aborigines.

speech.para: Senator Alston's defence of Mr Ruddock's comments in Le Monde in question time today continued the myth making about indigenous issues that this government is continuing to perpetuate, continued the rewriting of history that this government seems to want to do and continued the denial of truth on indigenous affairs in this community. Senator Alston gave Mr Ruddock his full support, we heard. He said that he was trying to paint a historical picture. By saying this, Senator Alston has shown his ignorance of fact and his lack of understanding of cultural difference.

Mr Ruddock's comments, coming at a time when the international view of Australia's relationships with indigenous peoples was improving due to the positive images of reconciliation portrayed by the Olympics, can only be described as ignorance in the extreme. As minister with responsibility for reconciliation, it is simply outrageous that he shows no respect for cultural difference, simply viewing other cultures through his own personal cultural mores. This is very basic stuff. There are principles taught through cross-cultural training—training that would be funded by his own department that goes to concepts like recognition and respect. These are fundamentals to the concept of reconciliation—fundamentals that this minister, and the Prime Minister, by not repudiating his words, have obviously abandoned. I suggest that Mr Ruddock take the opportunity of undertaking some cross-cultural training in order to stop the embarrassment of us as a nation in the international community.
I would like to quote from the Australian Anthropological Society, who have made a response to Mr Ruddock's comments in Le Monde. They say:

quote.para: The Australian Anthropological Society takes issue with the minister over both his original remarks and his subsequent defence of them as factual. As Minister for Reconciliation, Mr Ruddock should be very well aware that while indigenous Australian societies had not invented the wheel, at least for transport, this should play no objective part in an explanation of the indigenous history of poor and discriminatory treatment by governments, government agents and individual citizens.

talk.start.para: —What an ignorant remark.
—This is a letter from the Australian Anthropological Society. To call them ignorant is ignorance itself. They go on:

quote.para: Technological sophistication as measured by the standards of western civilisations has absolutely nothing to do with the sophistication of social, religious, linguistic or other dimensions of a given society. Indeed, the human capacity to learn and change is universal and is not tied specifically to any particular technological process.
Mr Ruddock should be well aware that such `facts' he refers to are precisely the kind that have been, and continually are, used to legitimate exclusion, and disadvantage.

talk.start.para: —Senator Campbell and Senator Schacht, if you wish to have a conversation, don't do it across the chamber.
—It is better than listening to this twaddle.
—Order! Senator Campbell! I would ask you to all come to order and not to reflect on other senators.
—They go on to say:

quote.para: We fail to see the relevance of his reference to the time of contact. Taken at face value it appears to be based more on the fallacious view of the inevitable evolution of less complex societies into more complex ones as a result of contact history. Anthropology teaches amongst other things, that such views are factually erroneous.

speech.para: I suggest that Minister Ruddock take the opportunity of undertaking some cross-cultural training in order to ensure that he does not continue to embarrass us as a community internationally.
Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Ian Campbell, you are out of order, as is Senator Forshaw. It is most difficult to call somebody if there are other people standing around and not letting me have a fair look.

—What a lot of nonsense it is for the Labor Party to think that what Mr Ruddock said is in any way surprising in terms of the history of the way indigenous people around the world have been treated under colonial powers. Indigenous people of Australia of course have been put at some disadvantage, as were the North American Indians, the Eskimos, the South American indigenous people and indigenous people everywhere when sophisticated European powers moved in on hunter-gatherer type populations. But the difference, and the big difference, which the Labor Party should acknowledge with the Australian population is that the Australian government, especially in more recent years, has recognised the problems that our indigenous people face. It has done an enormous amount to seek to overcome these problems and to ensure that their disadvantage ends and that they are able to participate in the society which is modern Australia in a manner which is consistent with their community values and culture.

speech.para: It is an absolute beat-up, this whole debate and criticism of Philip Ruddock. The Labor Party is just beating the Aboriginal drum, seeking to make it look as if the people of this country are not concerned about and determined to improve the disadvantage suffered by the Aboriginal people. Since the 1967 referendum which gave the federal government power to make laws specifically for indigenous Australians, the Commonwealth government has spent some $24 billion on indigenous specific programs, including $20 billion in the last 15 years. That is a very mighty statement of the recognition which the Commonwealth government—when it has been in the hands of the Labor Party as well as the coalition—has given to programs to overcome the disadvantage suffered by indigenous people.

I think it is pretty important to say, however, that it was the Fraser government which, more than any other government, recognised the need for Aborigines to be provided with land. The Fraser government conducted a program of purchasing stations in remote areas around Australia so that the Aborigines who had become fringe dwellers could return to properties and re-establish their community structure according to their own cultural system, which is to share and not to put total emphasis on the individual and the rights of the individual. In these communities the Aborigines were able to re-establish a sharing culture. It was very important that that was recognised. It is one of the things that has happened in recent years: there has been a great recognition of, and respect for, the fact that the Aborigines do have a different kind of culture from us

In recent years, Aboriginal housing and home ownership have improved remarkably. School retention rates have improved significantly. It is true that they lag behind non-indigenous rates. But the point is that it is recognised that education is the key to the door of the world for Aborigines, so making sure they have a formal education as well as job skill education is a high priority of this government. This government has an indigenous employment strategy which emphasises the need for job skill education and provides special funding for Aborigines who wish to establish small businesses. Infant mortality rates have dropped substantially. In general, Aboriginal indigenous health has improved incredibly over the last 20 years because the Commonwealth government has recognised the problems indigenous people face. As I said, it is total and absolute hypocrisy for the Labor Party to be criticising Philip Ruddock in this matter. Everybody knows there was a terrible problem with the Aborigines in terms of health and in terms of their level of disadvantage in the community, but Australia has a proud record now. All legal discrimination on the basis of race and colour has gone, and we have bent over backwards to ensure that Aborigines have an equal chance in our society. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —As Senator Eggleston has said, all legal discrimination has gone in this area, but I do not think that is the issue that is before us. The issue before us is the fact that the Aboriginals are still at a disadvantage in terms of the attitude of many people to them and in terms of their ability to get a fair deal in society. What happens in that situation is that people are going to feel very vulnerable—and so they should. And if words are said in that situation—and I do not say that Mr Ruddock said these words to wound—then that ought to be corrected. What this debate is all about is that the impression that has been created by the words of the minister for reconciliation has not been repudiated, has not been set aside in the strong terms one would hope it would be. We are not saying that, in the course of an hour's discussion with people overseas, Mr Ruddock has deliberately gone about trying to wreck reconciliation; we are not saying that at all. What we are saying is that having made that error, it ought to be corrected by government, by people who are here—by the government generally—and that has not been done. That is the problem in this instance.

speech.para: The use of words, the context in which they are used and the people that say them are vital to the interpretation that you make of them. If a sentence like `You do not look well' is said by my wife Lillian, I take it that it is said with a great deal of tenderness and with care for my health. If my doctor says, `You do not look well', I take that as a statement of fact. If people on the preselection panel say, `You do not look well', I would say that had an ominous tone about it.

talk.start.para: —You know they want your job, Barney.

—Exactly, Senator Patterson. And if that sentence is said by a gunman, I would say it had a sinister connotation to it. So when these words are used by the minister for reconciliation overseas in an interview with the media in France and in the United States, those words are going to take on a particular meaning. The meaning is going to be that somehow we in Australia regard Aboriginals, the indigenous people, as inferior, as some group of people that need to be raised up by us because they are not capable of being raised up by themselves; that they do not have a dignity that is commensurate with ours; that their cultural life is somehow inferior to ours; and that they have a history that is to be pitied. If those are the connotations that the words might have, then it is incumbent on the government of which Mr Ruddock is a member to make it very clear here and now that that is not what was intended.

speech.para: As Senator Schacht has said, Mr Ruddock has a fine record in this area. But on this occasion he has created a situation where the press has reported in a particular way. Now, the press can be wrong but, if it has reported in a particular way, it is then incumbent on the government to come out and to state that any incorrect inference that might have been drawn from the statements by the minister is wrong. That has not happened. Senator Eggleston did not get up and say, `Look, you've got it wrong. If Mr Ruddock has said that, and that has led to a particular interpretation being made, this government apologises. It is wrong. It is not correct at all.' Senator Eggleston did not get up and do that. He got up and said what a fine record the government has in this area. What we need is a strong affirmation that any wrong interpretation of Mr Ruddock's statements is incorrect and is repudiated by the government. That is what ought to happen here and now before this debate finishes. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In my first speech in this chamber I had occasion to describe Senator Cooney, whom I knew before I came into this chamber, as a gentleman, which caused a bit of mirth on both sides of the chamber. But nobody actually objected to my description of him as a gentleman. Since then, and I have been here for a year, my description of him has only been reinforced. Today we have seen Senator Cooney again behave in a gentlemanly manner because, instead of being like other opposition members, who habitually make any comments about people on the government side into a personal attack and personal vilification, Senator Cooney generously said that Mr Philip Ruddock has an outstanding record in his advocacy of human rights and that his words might have been misinterpreted. I think he is quite correct both in his sentiment and also in his interpretation. I have no doubt whatsoever that Mr Philip Ruddock's words have been wrongly interpreted and given the wrong connotation.

speech.para: However, Senator Cooney also said that the government should very firmly put the record straight by saying, `He did not say that. That was not his intention.' Senator Cooney said the debate is about the wrong impression having been made which must be forcefully set aside. I think there Senator Cooney is wrong, because the debate is not about setting aside a wrong impression; the debate is not about Aboriginals in Australia still being disadvantaged, therefore they feel vulnerable and therefore they should be reassured at all times. I think we have gone beyond that. In Australia everyone who is Australian should feel the same confidence that he or she is a citizen of this country of equal standing. They do not need people to pander to their self-esteem. They should by right have their self-esteem. This is what the government's programs are all about.

The government's programs are aimed at emphasising and repairing those inadequacies facing the indigenous community in our society so that they have every opportunity to restore them with the full citizenship rights in this country, like everyone else. And part of that is not to pamper them, not to nurse them. They must face facts and we must face facts that every one of us faces the same issue in this nation, and part of this issue is the facts of history. History has happened, and what happened in the past should not dominate how we face the future. That is the important issue. That is the government's position. Our entire program of providing assistance to those people in our community from an indigenous background is to give them the opportunity and all the resources they need so that they could confidently stand on their feet without having to depend on other people sparing their feelings.

Senator McLucas in her opening comments did a very credible job as a spokesman for the anthropological society who had a particular view of what history meant. It is not Mr Philip Ruddock who is trying to rewrite history. History is what happened. It is those who deny that history has happened who are trying to rewrite history, such as those senators on the opposite side who are members of the Labor Party, because it suits their political purpose at the moment. She was quite right to say the Olympics that have just finished portrayed a positive image of reconciliation in Australia. That is exactly what happened, and the government supports that approach completely. It is not a case of pointing the finger and saying, `Wrongs were done to the Aboriginals in the past, therefore we must always carry this guilt.' It is not a question of guilt. What happened in history has happened in history. We need to face the future. The rewriting of history has many reasons. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak to this motion about the amazing remarks made by Mr Philip Ruddock, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation, recently and questions about it in the Senate today. One, the government did not repudiate his remarks. The minister, Senator Alston, on behalf of the government supported his remarks. Mr Ruddock has put out a statement or made comment that what he was reported as saying in Le Monde magazine of 2 September were taken out of context. I have read part of the interview and the questions and the answers and I do not think the reporting in the Australian press can be taken out of context. The question was:

quote.para: Why are Aborigines still the most disadvantaged minority in Australia?

speech.para: The answer was:

quote.para: Of all indigenous peoples on the planet, if you compare them with Canadian or American Indians, Australian Aborigines came into contact with developed civilisations the latest. The Aborigines were hunter-gatherers. They had no knowledge of the wheel. They survived, thanks to their ingenuity, in a very difficult environment.

speech.para: And on it goes. I do not think you can claim that that is taken out of context at all. More importantly, I point out to the minister that today's news clips from Media Monitors has a report from the Washington Post saying that it is revealed that Mr Ruddock made similar statements to what appeared in Le Monde. It states:

quote.para: Indigenous Australians did not invent the wheel or have chariots and had little contact with developed civilisations.

speech.para: So, on two different occasions, Mr Ruddock has made similar remarks. I do not you think can use the first offence of a politician caught out or taken out of context. His remarks are totally in context and have been accurately reported. We have always pointed out that it is a bit odd that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs is not entrusted with the job of minister for reconciliation. We all know that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, who was given the reconciliation job, in his own ham-fisted way and foot-in-the-mouth ability, would make such a mess of it that it would destroy any opportunity. So the job has been handed over to somebody else. It was given by the Prime Minister, you might say as a poison chalice, to Mr Ruddock, a factional opponent within the Liberal Party of New South Wales.

As I mentioned earlier today in the debate on immigration, Mr Ruddock has a long history of being a small `l' Liberal with a commitment to human rights both within Australia and overseas. I have been a member of the Amnesty International Parliamentary Group as long as I have been in this place—since 1987. In the past, Philip Ruddock has been an executive member of the Amnesty International Parliamentary Group and has been vigorous and without fear or favour when he held positions promoting and supporting human rights all around the world. I compliment him for that. But since he became a minister in this government, dominated by the mean-spirited attitude of the present Prime Minister, we have seen what I would call the sad demise of Philip Ruddock as a small `l' Liberal.

We have now had what I think is the ultimate commentary on his position. Amnesty International has asked him to stop wearing their badge in his lapel. It embarrasses them to have him identified as a member of Amnesty International when he has put legislation through this parliament on immigration matters which is contrary to Amnesty International's notion of human rights. He has now made remarks on reconciliation which I suspect would go down well in some areas of the conservative or racist sector of our Australian society, and he would be clapped and cheered for them. Senator Ross Lightfoot has made similar remarks and has had to withdraw them. That is what those remarks go to.

What we need from this government and from the minister is a complete apology so that we can get on with the basis of decent reconciliation in Australia. Until we get that simple statement from the Prime Minister `I am sorry' or `We are sorry,' we will not get on with decent reconciliation in this country. That is the major barrier to it. Then we will no longer have the sad case of Minister Ruddock being an apologist for the policies of this government on reconciliation. (Time expired).

talk.start.para: —In response, I am not sure I can be as gracious towards Senator Cooney as my colleague Senator Tchen was in calling him a gentleman and more than that, but I will agree with Senator Cooney on one point—that is, words are bullets. That is where our agreement begins and ends. Also, I want to requote what Senator Schacht said—that is, he seemed to think that Minister Ruddock was given a poison chalice. The point I am leading to is, if words are bullets, then who was it from your side who said that to take the shadow ministry of Aboriginal affairs was indeed nothing short of being a toilet cleaner on the Titanic? Who said that? Words are bullets, Senator Cooney, as you and Senator Schacht get up to leave the chamber. You talk about poison chalices. The opposition believe it is a poison chalice to take the shadow ministry of Aboriginal affairs. Who said it? Where is your inquiry? Find that culprit. Until you do, I think those words have done more to damage reconciliation than anything else because the veil has fallen on the Labor Party. All they do with respect to Aboriginal affairs is try to make it a politically correct issue, squeezing everyone into their own political correctness. They mealy-mouth words for the public, but behind the scenes the truth is that no-one wants that portfolio and no-one really believes what they are saying.

speech.para: We have a minister in Philip Ruddock with a very good record in this area. Even the Deputy Chair of the Aboriginal Reconciliation Council, Sir Gus Nossal, has accepted that Mr Ruddock meant no offence at all by those words, and said that he fully accepted the words of Mr Ruddock when he said:

quote.para: I think he would have in no way intended insult or hurt to our indigenous colleagues.

speech.para: That is utterly correct because this minister has a fine record with respect to Amnesty International. And the nerve of one certain person in Amnesty International to contact Mr Ruddock and ask him to take off his badge—there was no more than one lowly, junior state leader of Amnesty International who had such sour grapes, and with this minister's record. I would like that person to retract their words. What an insult to a fine and competent minister.

I think the Labor Party have a duty to find the culprit who said that taking the shadow ministry for Aboriginal affairs was nothing more than being the cleaner on the Titanic. Until they do, they will have damaged reconciliation. The veil has really fallen on what the Labor Party believe in terms of the regard in which they hold Aboriginal affairs. They are fakes and they are frauds. They politicised it on every single level and while they were in government they actually failed to act. In contrast, this government believes not in the political correctness of the issue but in the reality—the practical reconciliation. I know you do not like hearing that word. You do not believe in that word. We do and we will continue to say it to counter your political correctness with regard to reconciliation. We are spending over $2.3 billion on indigenous affairs and that is in real terms. It is going straight to the heart of the need in health and in education. That is practical reconciliation. We accept that there is no quick fix on this but we certainly will not be bullied into political correctness and poring over words; rather, we will maintain our focus on practical reconciliation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —Yesterday the Senate ordered Senator Minchin, as the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, to present the Senate with a copy of a KPMG report on the Derby Tidal Energy Project commissioned by the Australian Greenhouse Office. The report was a due diligence report designed to provide the Commonwealth government with advice on the financial, technical and environmental viability of the project to allow the Commonwealth to assess proposals that it support the project. I am advised that a proviso of the Commonwealth's agreement with the consultant was that the report not be provided to a third party without the consultant's consent to protect the consultant's rights. I am advised that the report contains information provided on a commercial-in-confidence basis. I also am advised that publication of the report would coincide with the Western Australian government's tender process for the supply of electricity to the West Kimberley region. For these reasons, the government is not inclined to publish the report.

—I am not sure whether notice was given to the shadow minister, Senator Bolkus, in relation to this matter to enable him to be aware of what was taking place. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the statement:

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the statement.

speech.para: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —I present government responses to the following committee reports: the 25th report of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties on eight treaties tabled on 11 August 1999; the 29th report of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties entitled Singapore's use of Shoalwater Bay, development cooperation with PNG and protection of new varieties of plants; the report of the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee entitled Sale of ADI Limited; and the report of the Defence Sub-Committee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Visit to Defence establishments in northern Australia, 26 to 29 July 1999. I seek leave to incorporate the documents in Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

para.inline: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE 25TH REPORT OF THE JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE OF TREATIES

quote.para: The Government thanks the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties for the comprehensive consideration given to the eight treaty actions considered in the 25th Report. The Report makes recommendations relating to four treaty actions. The Government response to the recommendations is provided below.

para.inline: Double Taxation Agreements with South Africa and Malaysia

quote.para: The Government is pleased to note that the Committee recommended that binding treaty action be taken in respect of the following three taxation treaty actions:

para.inline: Agreement with South Africa for the Avoidance of Double Taxation and the Prevention of Fiscal Evasion with Respect to Taxes on Income and Protocol, done at Canberra on 1 July 1999 (6.46). The Agreement entered into force on 21 December 1999.

Protocol, done at Sydney on 2 August 1999, to amend the Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of Malaysia for the Avoidance of Double Taxation and the Prevention of Fiscal Evasion with Respect to Taxes on Income of 20 August 1980 (6.47). The Protocol to amend the Agreement entered into force on 27 June 2000.

Exchange of Letters constituting an Agreement to extend the Application of Certain Provisions of Article 23 of the Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of Malaysia for the Avoidance of Double Taxation and the Prevention of Fiscal Evasion with Respect to Taxes on Income of 20 August 1980 (6.48). Binding treaty action was taken on 9 November 1999.

quote.para: The Government offers the following response to the recommendation put forward by the Committee in relation to the taxation treaty actions considered by the Committee.

para.inline: 6.51 The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties recommends that:

the Australian Taxation Office extend its community and industry consultation program by inviting representatives of country-specific business organisations to participate in meetings of the Treaties Advisory Panel when treaty proposals relating to those countries are being considered.

quote.para: The Government has taken on board the Committee's recommendation and invited representatives from the country specific Business Councils to attend the Tax Treaties Advisory Panel Meeting on 5 May 2000.

For that meeting several Councils were invited to attend and asked for comment, but only a representative from the Russia-Australia Business Council was able to attend. Alternative methods of consulting interested Councils will be used where this is more convenient. For example, a presentation on proposed double taxation agreements was held for a Business Council in Sydney in August 2000.

para.inline: Fourth Amendment to the IMF's Articles of Agreement

quote.para: The Government is pleased that the Committee supported acceptance of the Fourth Amendment, done at Hong Kong on 23 September 1997, of the Articles of the Agreement of the International Monetary Fund of 27 December 1945 (3.68). Australia's instrument of acceptance is yet to be lodged.
The Government offers the following response to the recommendation put forward by the Committee in relation to the amendment.

para.inline: 3.66 The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties recommends that:

The Australian Government, at meetings of the governing bodies of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, actively support reform of these institutions, with a view to reducing duplication and waste in their operations and, as a longer term goal, their amalgamation.

quote.para: Australia has been an active participant in discussions about reform of the international financial system and these discussions include, as a key part, ensuring that the international financial institutions (IFIs), such as the IMF and World Bank, operate effectively.
In recent years, reform of the IFIs has included a number of measures:

a clearer focus by both institutions on their `core' mandates - with the IMF more focussed on promoting international macroeconomic stability and providing temporary financial assistance for balance of payments needs, and the World Bank focussed on longer-term development issues;
for the IMF, this has involved a strengthening of its economic surveillance role;
for the World Bank, this has involved a greater focus on the developmental impact of its activities rather than on inputs (eg loans processed, amount of funds lent);

both institutions have focussed on the elimination of unnecessary duplication and more effective collaboration (including recent pilot surveys of member country financial vulnerability and observance of internationally accepted standards and codes);
greater transparency of the policies, work and operations of the two institutions; and
an improvement of the range of financing facilities which better serve the needs of members of each institution.
The issue of reform of the IMF and World Bank will remain an important part of the discussions for reform of the international financial system in the period ahead.
The Australian Government will continue to actively participate in these discussions.

para.inline: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE RECOMMENDATIONS CONTAINED IN REPORT 29: SINGAPORE'S USE OF SHOALWATER BAY, DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION WITH PNG AND PROTECTION OF NEW VARIETIES OF PLANTS - JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON TREATIES:

Recommendation 1: The Department of Defence consult with the local business community during the preparation of future agreements with the Republic of Singapore and other countries on the use of Shoalwater Bay Training Area to ensure that its interests are incorporated to the maximum extent practicable (paragraph 2.148).

para.inline: RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE SENATE FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE REFERENCES COMMITTEE INTO THE SALE OF ADI LIMITED

quote.para: The Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee conducted an inquiry into whether the ADI sale had been conducted with prudence, discretion, integrity, skill and necessary propriety. The Committee released its report on 16 February 2000.

Under the terms of reference, the Senate Committee investigated whether the value of ADI and its assets were protected, whether a maximum price was realised and whether Australian national security and defence interest had been protected.

The Office of Asset Sales and IT Outsourcing (OASITO) in consultation with Defence provided written submissions to the Committee. Government Sale Team representatives (including Defence representatives) attended hearings conducted by the Committee on 26 October and 29 November 1999.
The Committee endorsed the sale process undertaken for the sale of ADI, providing no recommendations for consideration by Government. Specifically, the Committee found that:
OASITO and its advisers went to considerable lengths to ensure the integrity of the sale;
OASITO did the best it could to maximise the sale proceeds; and

There was no evidence that the sale of ADI to Transfield Thompson-CSF was likely to cause concern in the United States to the detriment of the close co-operation existing between Australia and the United States in relation to transfer of technology or related matters.

In Chapter 5, Structure of the Australian Defence Industry, Defence notes the concern expressed in evidence to the Committee `about the extent of consultation and co-operation between Defence and industry about acquisition policies and practices and their effect on the evolving structure of the industry'. These issues are currently on Defence's agenda, with the question of industry structure being a particular interest for the Defence and Industry Advisory Council.

A consistent theme in Defence industry policy over the last decade has been improvement of the Defence-industry relationship. The most recent review of this policy, the 1998 Defence and Industry Strategic Policy Statement, had as a major topic `culture and communication'. Eight of the forty-nine initiatives announced in the Statement addressed this issue. The most significant of these saw the revamping and extension of Defence's consultative arrangements with industry, including the establishment of the Defence and Industry Advisory Council (chaired by the Minister for Defence) the Capability Development Advisory Forum and the Industry Policy Consultative Forum. These bodies supplement on-going Defence-industry consultative forums namely:
Commercial Support Program Consultative Forum
Contracting Consultative Forum
Defence Exporters Council

In addition, Defence continues to incorporate industry associations and networks, and individual companies, into its decision-making processes on every appropriate occasion. A recent example of this has been the Private Financing Initiative workshop, co-hosted by the Australian Industry Group, at which approximately eighty industry participants contributed to the development of Defence's policy in this area.

para.inline: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE DEFENCE SUB-COMMITTEE OF THE JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE: REPORT ON THE VISIT TO DEFENCE ESTABLISHMENTS IN NORTHERN AUSTRALIA 26-29 JULY 1999
Recommendation 1: The Sub-Committee recommends that the Government conduct a review of the financial allowances paid to caretaker staff at the bare bases Scherger, Learmonth and Curtin

quote.para: Response: Many of the issues raised by personnel at RAAF Base Scherger involved matters already compensated for by the provision of District Allowance (the allowance that applies to all remote localities) and personal expenses unrelated to a posting.

However, the remaining issues were addressed in a depart-mental review, which concluded in November 1999, since the date of the Sub-Committee's visit. The outcome of the review was a payment, in addition to District Allowance, to all bare base caretakers of $1250 pa. An additional payment is also made to Scherger caretakers of $3750 pa, in recognition of the difficulties arising from regular use of the unsealed road between the base and Weipa township. Bare base allowance is payable fortnightly with District Allowance.

In accordance with the ADF Enterprise Productivity Arrangement: 1999-2002, the amounts of bare base allowance were increased on 8 June 2000 to $1290 and $3870 respectively, making a current payment of bare base allowance for Scherger caretakers of $5160 pa.

para.inline: Recommendation 2: The Sub-Committee recommends that the proposed changes to the Fringe Benefits Tax reporting requirements should be further reviewed to ensure that Australian Defence Force personnel are not disadvantaged by the unique circumstances and conditions under which they serve

quote.para: Response: Since the date of the Sub-Committee's visit, but prior to its report, the Government did conduct such a review, and provided an extensive range of exclusions from fringe bene-fits reporting for members of the ADF beyond the exclusion of housing assistance already noted by the Sub-Committee.

The legislation to report fringe benefits on Group Certificates was introduced to improve the fairness of the social security system. It is intended to ensure that the full value of remuneration is captured in respect to taxpayers' responsibilities for the various surcharges and child support payments, and to assess eligibility for access to social security benefits. The FBT is not paid by ADF members, but by Defence, as has been the case since 1986.

The many exclusions from FBT reporting requirements, additional to the total exclusion of housing assistance, are excellent results for ADF personnel and their families. They are the widest exclusions provided for any sector of the Australian community, reflecting the Government's recognition of the nature of military service.
Action continues within the Defence Organisation to address minor anomalies in the fringe benefits reporting requirements, as they become known.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 11 March 1998, on motion by Senator Stott Despoja:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I rise to address this private senator's bill, the Genetic Privacy and Non-discrimination Bill 1998. I am quite pleased to be able to speak to it. I think it is a very important piece of legislation and it is pleasing that the Senate has an opportunity to debate it. The bill, of course, was introduced by my colleague, the Deputy Leader of the Democrats, Senator Stott Despoja. She obviously tabled a second reading speech at the time. She is not able to speak to the bill as part of this debate until we get to the stage of closing the second reading stage, but certainly I am quite keen to outline and air some of the issues that the bill raises.

speech.para: The debate on the bill and on the issues it contains has been a long time coming. The bill that we are now debating was introduced by Senator Stott Despoja in March 1998 and the committee looking into the bill reported in March 1999. Since then there has been little action from the government on the issues that are raised in the report. I would recommend the report to anybody who is interested in this issue. It is quite a comprehensive report that was done by the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. The body of the report gives a good outline of the evidence and issues that were considered through the inquiry. There is a very detailed supplementary report, if you like, by Senator Stott Despoja. It is incredibly detailed. There are lots of footnotes and lots of good detail in that outline, which talks in great depth about not just the value and benefit of the bill but also the importance of the issues contained within it.

Currently, our privacy and discrimination laws are inadequate to deal with the unique and pressing issue of genetic information. It is of great concern to the Democrats that we have seen so little action in relation to this issue, despite many attempts to raise these concerns. We have had a glaring loophole in our laws which has allowed the first reported cases of discrimination on the basis of someone's genetic information to occur and go unpunished or even discouraged. These cases, and the probability of such discrimination, were not without warning. For years the Democrats have raised these pressing concerns in the parliament and in the community. Every attempt to have issues of genetics and, up until recently, gene technology adequately debated and explored has fallen flat. It has been a source of ongoing frustration to the Democrats that we have not been able to gain support from the larger parties for more comprehensive examination of some of these issues.

After the recent cases of discrimination were reported, there was understandable public outcry about the fact that there is no legislation in place to protect people's genetic privacy or to ensure that they cannot be discriminated against using that genetic information. The debate on this bill represents an ideal opportunity for the parliament to catch up and to adopt legislation that will protect the health information of Australians. We have lagged behind countries, such as the United States, which have implemented legislation designed to ensure an individual's genetic information cannot be used against them nor disclosed without their permission.

It is worth emphasising the fundamental aims of this bill. Its primary purposes are these: to establish an enforceable right to the privacy of genetic information of an individual by proscribing disclosure of such genetic information except with the authorisation of the individual or in other limited circumstances; to prevent any person from collecting a DNA sample from an individual for genetic analysis or storing or conducting a genetic analysis of such a sample except with that individual's authorisation; and to make discrimination based on genetic information unlawful. They are fairly fundamental and important aims, and worthy of support. They are also clearly a matter of concern. The fact that the Democrats are seeking to put such measures into legislation highlights the fact that currently people do not have that protection.

The views of the majority of the senators on the committee, whilst noting the importance of the issues raised by the bill that Senator Stott Despoja has introduced, suggested that we should not support the bill but instead suggested that the government should basically act on the issues, set up a national working party and give consideration to a reference to the Senate committee to undertake a more thorough examination of the issues and to draft legislation required to address these issues. Unfortunately, none of that has happened. It is a great concern that, despite this bill being around for more than two years—the issue has being raised for longer than that—and the report itself being around for now over a year and a half, no action has been taken by the government in this area. I urge senators to redress that situation by supporting this bill.

As I mentioned before, there are laws in other parts of the world that do address these issues. I know that Senator Stott Despoja has studied these laws around the world, just as I believe this bill has been discussed in other political institutions and by legislators around the world. In some ways, it has had more focus and debate in other countries than it has had here, which, again, is a great shame. The issues that the bill raises are ones that are important around the world. They are being acted on by governments such as the United States and individual states within the USA. To have no legislation of this type in any jurisdiction in Australia is a great omission.

The Democrats believe that an individual's genetic information should not be disclosed to any person or organisation without informed specific consent from that individual. That is what this bill seeks to enforce. At the same time, we know that the special place of research and its needs in Australia must also be balanced against the individual's right to privacy. For example, the disclosure of genetic information that does not contain personal identifiers for statistical or epidemiological studies should be possible with specific individual consent. Such exemptions from a general rule of individual specific consent allows for both the protection of individual privacy and the promotion of genetic research—two objectives which are often seen to be in conflict.

This bill was introduced in order to provide policy initiatives for the federal government because Australians' genetic information was at the time, and still remains, unprotected. The bill was also brought forward to raise related issues, including the regulation of Australian research and the property rights of genetic materials. The fundamental principle underlying this bill is that genetic privacy is unique and our legislation should recognise that. The other members of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee suggested that diagnostic genetic testing is not substantially different from any other diagnostic tests and generates few privacy and discrimination issues. That is something that the Democrats have a fundamental disagreement with. Unlike all other forms of information issues, including the information of an individual, genetic information crosses generational barriers. Disclosure of genetic information of an individual extends beyond the individual to surrounding blood relatives. It raises new and unique privacy and discrimination issues, and issues that are not protected currently under existing Australian legislation. It is something that many legislators, insurance companies and even the public service have failed to come to grips with, as is evidenced by the recent cases where people have been denied job opportunities, bank loans or health insurance, or had those threatened because of genetic information.

One of the criticisms or arguments against this bill has been that it is futuristic and that it is unnecessary because there are no cases of discrimination. However, that has clearly been proved to be wrong. The lack of action by this government has now been exposed. The clearly identified cases of discrimination against Australians who do not have protection highlights the gaps that currently exist.

The Democrats welcome the government's recently announced inquiry into the issue, but we call for a ban on the use of genetic information for any purpose besides personal, medical and limited employment cases in the interim. The issue has been around for a long time and the discrimination is happening now. Action now is important. Without a ban, Australians will remain unprotected and will continue to be discriminated against.

We also recognise that this bill cannot stand alone and that genetic privacy is best dealt with specifically and as part of a comprehensive privacy regime. I think it is worth noting that, again, it is the legal and constitutional committee that is currently considering the government's privacy legislation, which was sent there at the instigation of the Democrats to ensure that these issues are properly looked at, including the issue of genetic privacy. It is worth noting the need to continually push for issues such as this to be considered.

I think it would be useful to bring to the attention of the Senate some of the examples of genetic discrimination that have been brought to light over the past few months, just to highlight how the lack of protection is affecting Australians now. I know that Senator Stott Despoja has repeatedly drawn the attention of the chamber to these cases, including during question time. In the context of this debate, they are more relevant than ever. A report of a research project in New South Wales released in August demonstrated that 54 people had indicated they had been discriminated against on the basis of the results of genetic testing. When the Minister representing the Attorney-General in this place was asked a question about this report and other related issues of genetic discrimination, not only did she have no knowledge of the report; she failed to offer any hope or indication that the government would seek to address this issue quickly and comprehensively.

One example of this discrimination is that of a 34-year-old ophthalmologist who was refused a bank loan for equipment unless he took out income insurance. The insurance company required him to pass a genetic test for myotonic dystrophy, a muscle disease that runs in his family. His loan was contingent on that genetic information being provided and his having to, if you like, pass the test to show that he did not have the gene. Fortunately, he discovered that was the case and he got the loan. Obviously, the question arises: what would have happened if he had discovered that he did have that gene?

Another case is that of a 37-year-old quality assurance manager who was refused an increase in an income insurance policy after a genetic test showed that he had a predisposition to Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, or CMT, which is a hereditary progressive disorder that primarily affects the feet, legs and hands. In another example, an 18-year-old school leaver was refused a Public Service job—so we are talking about the Australian Public Service also being culpable on this issue—unless he took a test for late onset Huntington's disease. Having seen his mother suffer from this, he did not want to take the test because he preferred not to know. He had to appeal twice before he was able to overturn this refusal. He was eventually offered the job, but with reduced superannuation benefits.

These are cases that have been documented already, but they are only those that have been sought out and documented. We do not really know to what extent discrimination is taking place or, for that matter, how often a patient's information is being used for research or other purposes without his or her consent. The Democrats maintain that genetic information should not be used to discriminate between individuals for health insurance or some other purpose.

The Investment and Financial Services Association has developed a draft policy, which we have some difficulties with and criticism of. But it is an attempt by the health insurance industry to grapple with an issue that the larger parties in this place have refused to grapple with and have refused to take a position on. We do have examples of insurance clients being charged higher premiums. For example, in Victoria we know that people with the Huntington's disease gene are being charged higher premiums; they are paying more for their health insurance. We have newspaper reports of insurance giants AXA, Colonial AMP and MLC using genetic information as part of an assessment of people's medical history.

IFSA maintains that it is a legal practice, and under current government laws it is. Unlike IFSA, the Democrats maintain that genetic information is not like other health information. It was certainly a matter of concern to us during the recent Senate committee hearings into the government's privacy bill when, despite all the privacy experts insisting that there is a difference between ordinary health information and genetic information, the insurance representatives maintained there is no such difference.

We are concerned that IFSA's policy, which is currently before the ACCC, will discourage sectors of the Australian community from undertaking possibly helpful gene tests. This is something that I think it is important to emphasise and something that the Democrats have certainly tried to emphasise. We also recognise that there are potentially enormous benefits from these new technologies, not least in the area of health. We do not want people to be discouraged from benefiting through the use of this technology. I highlight the concerns expressed by no less a person than the US President, Bill Clinton, when he said:

quote.para: We ... know that one of the main reasons women refuse genetic testing for susceptibility to breast cancer is the fear that the insurance companies may either deny them coverage or raise their rates to unaffordable levels.

speech.para: We should not fear a technology that has the potential to significantly reduce human suffering. We should not have a situation where people are reluctant to use beneficial technology because of a legitimate concern that information that comes to light may then be used against them.

This responsible and comprehensive legislation we are debating today is fundamental to appeasing these fears. While we recognise the attempt by the insurance industry to develop codes on this issue, we are concerned about the loopholes contained in those proposed guidelines and we are also concerned about voluntary codes. We know that, when it comes to self-regulation, voluntary codes can hide the potential activities of disreputable organisations and may disguise the fact that there is no legally enforceable guarantee of protection. We must have clear, accountable and transparent guidelines if the community is to have any faith in this technology and its benefits.

The other factor that is the key to achieving public faith and goodwill in the use of this technology is to ensure that the public is involved in these debates and that the parliament leads on these issues and does not sit back and leave it to the industry organisations. That is the aim, and has always been the aim, of this legislation: to bring about a realistic debate and consideration of genetic privacy issues.

The comprehensive report into this particular legislation was tabled last year, and the conclusions arising from it included the creation of a national working party and ongoing responsibility for the appropriate Commonwealth departments to monitor developments with a view to drafting legislation. Those were put forward instead of support for the bill. The report did recommend that the bill not proceed, pending further examination of the issues and the development of appropriate amendments to existing legislation. Unfortunately, more than 18 months later, this has not happened, despite the fact that the committee report was tabled back in March 1999. Certainly I am very supportive of this legislation and am very keen and pleased to contribute to the ongoing attempt by the Democrats to press this issue, highlighted through the parliamentary process and through other areas of community debate.

I would emphasise that genetic technology has the potential to bring great benefits to all humans. It is worth quoting from Senator Stott Despoja. You may be interested in her words which are contained in another interesting book that is also worth reading, Goodbye Normal Gene—a book that examines the wider social questions and impacts that genetic technology will bring to the new century. I think it is very important for legislators as well as the public to be familiar with this book. The foreword for that book was written by Senator Stott Despoja, and I endorse her words. She said:

quote.para: Genetic technology has the potential to bring great benefits ... based on the diversity of solutions contained in the genetic material of living organisms. At the same time, however, the rate of development of this powerful technology has raised new and complex ... issues.

speech.para: These are issues that this parliament—like parliaments all over the world—must address. We must start to act to address them. This bill provides a starting point in this debate. It is with a sense of pride that I note the role of the Democrats in bringing these cutting edge issues to the attention of the community and politicians. I urge other senators, other parties and others in the community to also contribute to the debate, to get more understanding of the issues and some of the real concerns that are expressed by people and to be more committed to acting to get protection in these important areas of genetic privacy and non-discrimination into our legislative regime.

The bill is significantly based on legislation that has come into law in the United States. On one level I think it is important to emphasise, as a way of demonstrating that it is quite a workable approach that is put forward, that it has been adopted in other jurisdictions. Some would suggest that it is not appropriate—indeed, others in the committee suggested that it was not appropriate—because of our different health care systems, if we compare health insurance situations between the US and Australia. But the Democrats believe that that is not an adequate argument; it is a furphy. Obviously there are differences in our health care systems but the fundamental issues of protecting genetic privacy and of being protected from discrimination on the grounds of genetic information are not things that are based on your health system; they are fundamental rights that people should have and currently do not have. So we do not endorse that suggestion. We believe it is appropriate and worth while to compare and, where workable, employ situations and legislation that have been adopted in other jurisdictions—and, clearly, this is one case where that is appropriate. (Time expired)
